posts.post_content:
[Dryad Arbor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dryad Arbor) lives directly underneath the Green Sun, apparently. I like that casting this card for ![Variable Colorless](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=X&type=symbol)=![0](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=0&type=symbol) isn't dead.  
  
@ Kalatash: Yes, two shuffles, for somewhat daft reasons. The card [Comandeer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Comandeer) lets an opponent take control of this spell. Unless you'd want your opponent to shuffle your card into their library, the shuffle effect has to be written twice, or else Commandeer would let them sort of literally steal your card. :)  
  
I think there's a rule in the Comprehensive Rules somewhere that says if you'd shuffle multiple times without intervening stuff happening, you and your opponents can agree to just shuffle in an obvious/appropriate way.  
  
The worst "do I really have to shuffle again" offender was [Mind's Desire](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind's Desire). Cool card, but resolving it could take fifteen minutes, sometimes. Bleh.  
  
The mathematician/physicist/old-school-astronomer in me loves the perfect use of the obscure-ish word "Zenith" on this cycle of cards.
posts.html:
Dryad Arbor lives directly underneath the Green Sun, apparently. I like that casting this card for = isn't dead.

@ Kalatash: Yes, two shuffles, for somewhat daft reasons. The card Comandeer lets an opponent take control of this spell. Unless you'd want your opponent to shuffle your card into their library, the shuffle effect has to be written twice, or else Commandeer would let them sort of literally steal your card. :)

I think there's a rule in the Comprehensive Rules somewhere that says if you'd shuffle multiple times without intervening stuff happening, you and your opponents can agree to just shuffle in an obvious/appropriate way.

The worst "do I really have to shuffle again" offender was Mind's Desire. Cool card, but resolving it could take fifteen minutes, sometimes. Bleh.

The mathematician/physicist/old-school-astronomer in me loves the perfect use of the obscure-ish word "Zenith" on this cycle of cards.

Posted By: LordRandomness (8/21/2012 4:10:56 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
One of the most underrated aspects of this card are the impact it has on deck building. It saves you space. For example, let's say you run 3 [Rafiq](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rafiq) in your bant deck, which also runs 3 [Sigarda](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sigarda). With this available, you can instead run only one Rafiq, one Sigarda, and three or four Green Sun's Zenith without hurting consistency. In fact, you're probably *helping* it.  
  
Of course in the example above, I only mentioned two creature cards. In actual gameplay, you can snatch *any* green creature from your deck as you see fit. That's the definition of consistency.  
  
In laymen's terms, that means assuming you have three Green Sun's Zenith's, that even one-of's in your deck can be consistently brought into play as if you had four. And four-of's can have the consistency of an eight-of with the addition of a fourth Green Sun's Zenith.
posts.html:

With this available, you can instead run only one Rafiq, one Sigarda, and three or four Green Sun's Zenith without hurting consistency. In fact, you're probably helping it.

Of course in the example above, I only mentioned two creature cards. In actual gameplay, you can snatch any green creature from your deck as you see fit. That's the definition of consistency.

In laymen's terms, that means assuming you have three Green Sun's Zenith's, that even one-of's in your deck can be consistently brought into play as if you had four. And four-of's can have the consistency of an eight-of with the addition of a fourth Green Sun's Zenith.

posts.post_content:
Essentially this card gives you 4 (or more) extra copies of whichever creature would best suit you at the time you cast it.  
  
No reason not to throw 4 of these in any deck that has green creatures.  
  
Also: [Painter's Servant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Painter's Servant)
